Problem:
Consider a differential equation governing heat distribution \\(u_t = ku_{xx}\\), with initial heat distribution function \\(u(x, 0) = f(x)\\). An operation \\(g(u) = e^{wt}u\\) is applied, where \\(w\) is a constant, which alters the heat distribution dynamically.

Knowing the heat distribution at time \\(T\\), can we accurately trace back and determine which transformations (\\(g(u)\\), \\(h(u)\\), or both) were applied, based solely on the observed distribution?
Explanation: Due to the linear and reversible characteristics of the transformations \\(g(u)\\) and \\(h(u)\\) over the linear heat equation, multiple transformation sequences could yield the same heat distribution at time \\(T\\). Consequently, it is not feasible to uniquely identify the interventions merely by observing the distribution at time \\(T\\).
